Submarine crews manage sleep schedules through a system called "watchstanding," which involves rotating schedules where crew members are divided into groups and work in shifts. Each crew member is assigned a specific watch schedule, which usually lasts for six hours, followed by a six-hour sleep period. This means that the crew can be awake and alert for 12-18 hours at a time, with three to four watches being manned continuously.

During extended missions, submarine crews need to mitigate the effects of sleep deprivation to maintain their focus and mental acuity. Crew members are trained to develop good sleep habits, such as finding a consistent bedtime and avoiding caffeine and alcohol. Additionally, submarines are equipped with "napping stations," where crew members can take additional short naps to make up for lost sleep. 

Submarine crews are also given access to a range of resources that can help them manage the effects of sleep deprivation. Some of these resources include high-quality nutritional supplements, such as multivitamins and energy drinks, and a range of mental wellness programs, such as meditation and cognitive therapy. Submarine crews also engage in regular physical exercise and recreational activities to help maintain their mental health and prevent boredom.

Overall, submarine crews are highly trained to manage sleep schedules and mitigate the effects of sleep deprivation during extended missions. These skills and resources help keep them alert and focused, allowing them to execute their missions successfully.
